title: Contenta Makes Your Content Happy
summary: Contenta is a Drupal distribution that gives you modern API capabilities out-of-the box with JSON API, which amongst other features allows you to fetch nested resources in one request. It’s ready to feed content to your JavaScript powered website, phone app, TV, or even the mythical fridge application.
author: Mateu Aguiló Bosch

title: Request a Node
summary: Request a single node by UUID using the JSON API module. This tutorial explains the basics of JSON API requests.
author: Contenta team

title: The JSON API output
summary: Understand all of the parts in the output of a JSON API response: resource object, attributes, relationships and metadata.
author: Contenta team

title: Working with Relationships
summary: Relationships in JSON API allow you to reference related pieces of content. This video describes how to interact with relationships in JSON API
author: Contenta team

title: Collections
summary: Collections are the best way to get a listing of entities for a particular resource. They are the alternative to Views in the decoupled world.
author: Contenta team

title: Filters for Collections
summary: Add constraints to the items you get back from your collections. You can execute any Entity Query as a JSON API filter, but you will need to learn the syntax.
author: Contenta team

title: Sparse Fieldsets
summary: If you are getting too much data back from the JSON API server, then you can benefit greatly from using sparse fieldsets.
author: Contenta team

title: Embedded Resources
summary: This is the most important feature of JSON API. Avoid multiple requests to Drupal by choosing what related entities to embed in your response.
author: Contenta team

title: Nested Filters
summary: Nested filters are useful when you want to find content based on the values of the attributes in the related entities. They take the filters to a new level.
author: Contenta team

title: Relation Endpoints
summary: JSON API comes with two extra endpoints to make it easier to deal with relationship. The related and the relationship endpoints will help with your relationship operations.
author: Contenta team

title: Sorting Responses
summary: Sort the results of a collection. It is also useful to find the first or last elements based on a sort criteria.
author: Contenta team

title: Creating New Records
summary: Learn to use the POST method if you need to create new records using JSON API. Write operations are typically available only to authenticated users.
author: Contenta team

title: Updating Records
summary: The PATCH method can be used to alter existing entities in the Drupal backend. Write operations are typically available only to authenticated users.
author: Contenta team

title: Removing Records
summary: When you need to remove content from Drupal using JSON API you can use the DELETE method.
author: Contenta team

title: Translation Support
summary: You can access natively the different translations of a content entity using JSON API.
author: Contenta team

title: Introduction to OAuth2
summary: Quick review and understanding of OAuth2.
author: Contenta team

title: Installation and set up
summary: Learn how to install and configure the Simple OAuth module.
author: Contenta team

title: Password Grant
summary: Authenticate requests using the password grant.
author: Contenta team

title: OAuth 2 Scopes and Drupal Roles
summary: OAuth2 grants are represented as Drupal roles. Learn how those work.
author: Contenta team

title: Refresh Token Grant
summary: Generate a new valid token when it expires by refreshing it.
author: Contenta team

title: Client Credentials Grant
summary: Authenticate requests using the client credentials grant.
author: Contenta team

title: Authorization Code Grant
summary: Authenticate requests using the authorization code grant.
author: Contenta team

title: Implicit Grant
summary: Authenticate requests using the implicit grant.
author: Contenta team

title: The Hidden Costs of Decoupling
summary: Decoupled Drupal has been well understood at a technical level for many years now. While the implementation details vary, most Drupal teams can handle working on decoupled projects. However, we’ve heard the following from many of our clients
author: Andrew Berry

title: Should you Decouple?
summary: One of the major topics of discussion in the Drupal community has been decoupled (or headless) Drupal. Depending on who you ask, it’s either the best way to build break-through user experiences, or nothing short of a pandemic. But what exactly is a decoupled architecture?
author: Andrew Berry

title: The 3 C's + the 1 D of Drupal: Why Decoupled Matters
summary: Decoupled has been in place for a few years, but the Open Source and Drupal community are really beginning to rally around it, as evidenced by more than 100 professionals gathering in NYC last weekend at 30 Rock.
author: Josh L.

title: Incredible Decoupled Performance with Subrequests
summary: In my previous post, Modern Decoupling is More Performant, we discussed how saving HTTP round-trips has a very positive impact on performance. In particular, we demonstrated how the JSON API module could help your application by returning multiple entities in a single request. Doing so eliminates the need for making an individual request per entity.
author: Mateu Aguiló Bosch

title: Subrequests Specification
summary: Specification for the Subrequests project.
author: Mateu Aguiló Bosch

title: 4 Benefits of decoupled architecture for enterprise digital marketers
summary: A non-developer focused article on decoupled architecture from Mediacurrent's Shellie Hutchens.
author: Shellie Hutchens

title: Decoupled Drupal and Ember
summary: This is the first in a series of articles that will document lessons learned while exploring using Ember as a decoupled client with Drupal.
author: Blaine

title: Decoupled static music site using Drupal + Pushtape Cassette
summary: Looks like a fun way to play with decoupled Drupal and music.
author: Farsheed Hamidi-Toosi

title: React and Drupal 8 with JSON API 2/3
summary: If you're looking at experimenting with decoupled Drupal be sure and read this post. JSON API is a great way to expose you content to a decoupled frontend app.
author: Christophe

title: Progressively Decoupled Drupal Approaches
summary: This blog post features some compelling approaches which reflect a wide spectrum of possible ways to implement Drupal in a progressively decoupled fashion without abandoning the things that make Drupal great on the front end.
author: Preston So

title: Between the Cracks of Decoupled (Drupal) Architecture
summary: In this article Campbell Vertesi provides a very insightful look at the issues that can arise when you add the complexity of a decoupled architecture.
author: Campbell Vertesi

title: Drupal and Graphql with React and Apollo
summary: This blog post shows how you can easily use Drupal 8, React, GraphQL, and Apollo to build an app that displays a list of articles.
author: Vasi Chindris

title: Decoupling in drupal 8 based on a proven model
summary: Matt Davis of Mediacurrent introduces us to a module that provides the ability to progressively decouple blocks in Drupal 8.
author: Matt Davis

title: Re-learning accessibility for a decoupled front end
summary: Tobias Williams reminds us that when decoupling Drupal, we need to thinking more about accessibility. A good refresher.
author: Tobias Williams

title: Using Drupal 8 contact forms via REST
summary: A solution to a commonly requested feature in decoupled sites.
author: Sven Decabooter

title: Decoupled Drupal Hard Problems: Image Styles
summary: As part of the API-First Drupal initiative, and the Contenta CMS community effort, we have come up with a solution for using Drupal image styles in a decoupled setup.
author: Mateu Aguiló Bosch

title: Decoupled Drupal Hard Problems: Schemas
summary: The Schemata module is our best approach so far in order to provide schemas for our API resources. Unfortunately, this solution is often not good enough. How can we improve this situation?
author: Mateu Aguiló Bosch

title: Decoupled Drupal Hard Problems: Routing
summary: We know how to create custom paths in Drupal, but in a decoupled scenario things can get trickier.
author: Mateu Aguiló Bosch

title: Single-sign on (SSO)
summary: Contenta can be a SSO authentication server for your applications regardless what technologies you used to build them.
author: Jingsheng Wang

title: Contenta Docker: Initial Install
summary: "Contenta provides a Docker project to get you up and running with Contenta super easy. In this screencast
image: we run through the install of Contenta via Docker Compose."
author: Miscelaneous

title: Contenta Docker: Adding a Consumer
summary: "Building off of the Contenta Docker project
image: we are going to add a Polymer frontend application to comunicate with our decoupled backend."
author: Miscelaneous

title: Contenta Docker: GraphQL and Apollo
summary: "In addition to REST
image: Contenta includes an instance of GraphQL. In this screencast
link: we'll use the apollo-client web component to pull data into our Polymer frontend application."
author: Watch Video

title: How to install Contenta headless Drupal on a Digital Ocean droplet
summary: "Installing it is generally a straightforward process
image: but the documentation does assume a level of Drupal knowledge that I don’t possess."
author: Miscelaneous

title: JSON-RPC to decouple everything else
summary: "During the week of DrupalCon we discussed some limitations decoupling Drupal. We concluded that we need a reliable
image: flexible and secure way for Drupal developers to decouple everything else."
author: Miscelaneous
